document.docAuthor: Mendoça, Maria Cleide De & Fernandes, Liliane Henriques
document.docTitle: Rhynchocyrtus klausi Mendoça & Fernandes, 2007, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Rhynchocyrtus gen. nov. (Collembola, Entomobryidae) from the Southeast and Northeast Brazilian regions

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Rhynchocyrtus gen. nov. (Collembola, Entomobryidae) from the Southeast and Northeast Brazilian regions

subSubSection.paragraph:
Thorax II to abdomen IV with pseudopores; abomen II with two bothriotrichia and one macrochaeta; abdomen III with three bothriotrichia and three macrochaetae; abdomen IV with two bothriotrichia and 18 macrochaetae arranged as in
Figs 14–17
. Macrochaetae on the head only in the anterior region.

Type locality.
National Park of Tijuca, Rio de Janeiro city, Rio de Janeiro State, Brazil . Found in litter and soil.

Type material.
Brazil , Rio de Janeiro State, Rio de Janeiro city, National Park of Tijuca, holotype male on slide Nº
1674, 08
.iii. 2007 , M. C. Mendonça, coll.; two paratypes on slide Nº 53 CM/ MNRJ ,

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1-11.
Rhynchocyrtus klausi
gen. nov. sp. nov.
: 1, antennal segment IV; 2, antennal segment III; 3, antennal segment I; 4, labral chaetotaxy and frontal macrochaetotaxy of the head; 5, labial chaetotaxy; 6, mandibles; 7, maxilla; 8, maxillary palp; 9, eyes and interocular setae; 10, trochanteral organ; 11, distal part of the tibiotarsus and claw of the leg III.

FIGURES 12–20.
Rhynchocyrtus klausi
gen. nov. sp. nov.:
12,. Collophore. 13. Tenaculum. 14. Distribution of pseudopores, trichobotriae and macrochaetae. 15. Trichobothrial complex of the abdominal segment II. 16. Trichobothrial complex of the abdominal segment III. 17. Trichobothrial complex of the abdominal segment IV. 18. Dorsal view of the manubrium. 19. Dental tubercle and some neighboring setae. 20. Distal part of the dens and mucro.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks.
Rhynchocyrtus klausi
gen. nov. sp. nov
, widely distributed throughout forest litter and soil, was also found in sand dunes in the restinga ecosystem. Another species of the new genus, that will be described later, was collected from remnant Atlantic rainforest soil in Pernambuco State, in the Northeast Brazilian region, 2300 km far from Rio de Janeiro State as well as in the Southeast Brazilian region, extending the genus occurrence area (
Fig. 21
). The species from the Northeast region shows the same mouth structure but it has the different color pattern (
Figs 22–23
) than
Rhynchocyrtus klausi
gen. nov. sp. nov.
described and illustrated here (
Figs 24–25
).
Etymology. This species is kindly dedicated to our colleague Dr. Klaus Dieter Sautter.
